segments.text: My first question concerns your academic background.
What took you into oceanography?
Interest, undergraduate training?
Oh, I guess it was being a kid growing up on the waterfront, and then went off to college, and I found out they paid people to do this kind of stuff.
I didn't believe it.
Well, having been growing up on the waterfront and being in the commercial fisheries and
I was just kind of interested in fishing and that sort of thing.
Where did you grow up in Waterford?
On North Shore of Long Island.
Obviously you weren't from Seattle, I'm about to ask.
And where did you do your undergraduate training?
University of New York.
And I ended up doing my graduate training there too.
I did one year out here in 59-60 after I got my bachelor's degree.
And I ended up going back for my master's and PhD at Cornell.
Basically, it was more of a question of speed.
I thought I had places to go and people to see and things to do.
At that time, the graduate program here was extremely tedious.
It was taking people seven or eight years to get out.
You couldn't have made your notionography at Cornell.
Well, they had an oceanographer there, but we were in the College of Agriculture in the Department of Conservation.
And they had a guy there who was primarily teaching some service courses.
But he did run a little program on Long Island.
effluent waste problem on the south shore back when pollution wasn't even an in thing to do, but we were working on pollution back in the late 50s and early 60s.
And this explains in your interest in ecology.
This directs you towards ecology?
Yeah, I believe so.

Again, I guess I have to sort of lean back on what I did as a kid growing up and hunting and fishing and, you know, sort of interested in the outdoors and it was an area I never even thought of, you know,
working at, you know, i.e.
making a living.
And then I, like I said, I went off to college and I found out they paid people to do this kind of stuff, but I just really couldn't believe it, you know.

And, of course, that was a crazy time when right after Sputnik went up, and it sure felt nice to have people, you know, writing you letters and saying, please come here, you know, we'll do this and we'll do that for you.
And so it was really kind of a, you know, the timing was right.
I don't know what happened, you know, I would have gone through later on, but that's the way, you know, it was in the late 50s, early 60s.
And you didn't take a break between your undergraduate training and your graduate training?
No.
You went straight through?
I went straight through.
Okay.
And was the University of Washington your first job?
No.
After I got my degree at Cornell, I went to Scripps, and I worked in the TUNA group, a thing called Scripps TUNA Oceanographic Research Group.
And I was there for about two and a half years.
And I did my thing, which was phytoplankton ecology.
After that, I went to Woods Hole for four years, doing basically the same thing, working with John Reiser and Dave Menzo and their group.
And then I spent two and a half years at the National Science Foundation, leaving Woods Hole in January of 71.
left the Science Foundation.
I was a staff associate in the oceanography section in June 73, and I came out here in June 73 and been here ever since, still doing basically my phytoplankton type of approach to food web ecology.
With whom did you work at Scripps now?
The guy in charge of the group was Morris Blackburn.
He was a transplanted Australian.
And his old plankton type was Alan Longhurst, who went back to England as a director of a lab in Plymouth.
And there was a phytoplankton, another phytoplankton type by the name of Bill Thomas.
And there was four principal, what you would call principal investigators there, a group of maybe a total of 15 people.
And we were trying to hook up the game of
phytoplankton, zooplankton into tuna with using physical parameters also.
It was sort of the ego systems approach before they even coined the term.
We didn't do any modeling per se.
Again, that really didn't come into vogue until much later, although our statistical analysis at
And then you, and you take this with you to Woods Hole, this technique with you to Woods Hole, and begin to work there.
But you don't work on tuna at Woods Hole.
No, no.

At tuna we, uh, the, the rye of the group was basically, uh, looking at food chain dynamics, uh, using a chemical approach, uh, looking at, uh, mass balances and things like this, rather than being overly concerned with population dynamics, uh,
the various species compositions of the various parts of the food chain.
We used a bulk approach.
We measured carbon, nitrogen, and things like that.
Now, how did you make contact with the University of Washington from NSF?
What prompted you to make a change for this?
Well, it was sort of a question of did I want to get back to the science or did I want to stay in the administration?

part and I thought I'd want to go back and do the science again and two and a half years is probably as long as you want to take off and what all I ended up doing was I let the word out I was looking for a job and this is the one of the ones that came in and one of the more attractive ones.
Now, while you were at NSF, I have several questions, one of the things I wanted to ask you about.
I have several questions, as a matter of fact, about grant giving and getting as it occurs on the level.
It has been suggested that in terms of creating the discipline of oceanography, that grant getting directs the nature or the direction of oceanography.
That is, oceanographers tend to petition the government for grants, not so much for their own research, but to do research like the NSF would like them to do.
Is that your experience?
Oh, there's a certain amount of truth to that.
You obviously, when you're writing a proposal, you're obviously going to write one that you think is going to be funded, otherwise you're just spinning your wheels.
There are certain in things, they're fads in science just like everything else.
The nice thing about at least the Science Foundation was that there was a number of different
offices you could go to if you had different kinds of problems in mind.
The big programs, of course, are more directed.
Not to say that that's necessarily bad.
I mean, direction is like the NORPACS thing where they're trying to...
The end result, obviously, is to try to predict weather so that when the IDOE office makes up their mind they're going to go
the kinds of problems that they're willing to fund.
But the oceanography section, per se, is a lot more open.
And I think, by and large, it's probably as open as you're ever going to get.
I believe the track record there shows that probably 10% of the funds each year are spent on flyers.
Things that, you know, it's a good idea.
I'm not really sure it's going to pay off.
probably another 15 to 20% of the money is spent each year on young people coming into the business.
Of course, that implies that they cut off the older guys, which they do.

But I think, by and large, the Science Foundation, and to some extent ONR, is the only two places in the government where you can get money to do the kinds of things you're interested in doing, much more so than, say, IRDA or EPA or NOAA.
what are more mission-oriented agencies.
So I think you can still do more or less what you want to do.
The thing at NSF, of course, is changing kind of rapidly.
I got in sort of at the tag end where most of the programs were staffed by rotators like myself.
You come out of academia, you plunk into the office for a couple years, and you knew you were going to go back out again.
And so that you would drag along your ideas of what you thought was good science.
But we've had so much trouble recruiting people to go to Washington, people just don't want to go, that we're ending up filling up all the program slots with career bureaucrats.
And that's not exactly a desirable way to go.
Well, with the reaction that we've had to the Nixon
foolishness and everything else, and also the consumer advocacy emphasis and everything else, we're getting stuck with a lot of accountability jazz, which I think is really a detriment.
Again, I look back at when I was there, we could walk through a grant in less than a day.
If a guy, you know, his kids weren't going to have any shoes, he wasn't going to get any food, and we had to get that grant out that day, we could walk the thing through in one day.
And there's no way that's going to happen anymore.
It has to go through so many review boards.
They just get to be more of a bother.
And I imagine it's a heck of a lot less fun being back in the Science Foundation now than it was when I was back there, just because you're always on the firing line a lot more.
We used to be fairly well protected from the bureaucrats and from Congress.
But I think Congress gets down
probably even to the division level now.

Back in the old days, if I had to quote the old days, it's not that old, but if anybody from Congress tried to contact anybody in the Science Foundation, there was always a roadblock that they had to go to first, and they couldn't get by him to get to you.
They had to tell him what they wanted, and he'd find a guy to answer, so that you never were in direct contact.
The political punch is getting down a lot lower now than it was back then.
And of course, we're running into all sorts of problems, again, with the foundation, which never existed and we never thought would exist just five years ago.
And that has to do with the reporting aspects.
And so back five, six, seven years ago, we did an awful lot of things on good faith, on goodwill.
And that's gone.
It's almost gone completely, which is unfortunate.
Because the other agencies, of course, always had that kind of an aspect to them.
So the Science Foundation was sort of the last stronghold of this thing.
We didn't have to theoretically convince our superiors that science was good every year.
But apparently, they're going to have to start doing that again.
There's also a move in Washington now to combine all of ocean grant-giving units into one large super unit, probably the Department of Commerce.
Do you approve of that?
I think that would be disastrous.
Basically, well, if it's strictly a grant-giving arm, I think that perhaps wouldn't be all that bad, mainly because it would be so darn big.
that the guys in one office aren't going to be talking to the guys in the other office.
So that you don't end up with a sort of monolithic uniform approach to the whole problem.
I think even though it's inefficient to have these separate groups operating by themselves, I mean from an administrative point of view they're very inefficient.
I think from a scientific point of view it's probably pretty darn good.
But I think the real disaster would be if
The major funding comes from the same organization that has its own in-house research capability.
We see this across the street here at PMEL, which is a NOAA lab, an ERL lab.
It's an environmental research lab.
And they do their own in-house research.
And theoretically, NOAA does extramural research also.
But as soon as a squeeze comes along, you know who gets the pinch?
We do.
And of course, they keep their money.
I mean, it's disruptive enough trying to keep your operation going from one year to the next now.
But if you ever got into the situation where you're always being second and third guessed by somebody else, like these people over here are second guessed by people in Boulder, Colorado.
And of course, their bosses sit back in Rockville, Maryland.
And they really have very little control on their life.
And I hate like heck to see us get, the academic area, get into the same situation.
So I just think that something where they glommed everything together in one group would be kind of bad.
The unfortunate thing is I think I see it coming.
And there are a number of things that are probably going to swing it if it does happen.
as we're having trouble with facility ships.
How do you keep these things funded?
How do you keep them going?
And I have a feeling that in the name of efficiency, we might get crammed into some sort of a mold.
I happen to be back at the foundation when the University National Oceanographic Laboratory System was being talked about as if they were going to do something.

it was a wonderful scheme if you read the whole Stratton report and sort of an appendix on the back they said as a matter of efficiency let's say we do something about funding and operating ships and of course that's the only thing that survived everything else went out the window and so I could see the need for running facilities driving the whole thing and
maybe something like that might happen.
The other thing, of course, that could come out of it is that you'd end up with two or three centers in the country and cutting everybody else off.
Again, this is sort of a problematical thing, whether something like this would happen.
But that's always a real, live possibility.
Well, now, actually, this is before your time, so to speak.
There was a policy at one time, particularly when ONR was first organized, of sort of giving blanket grants to institutions.
And then the institution was rather free to disperse the money among its various faculty members and researchers.
Would you like to see a return to some sort of system like that?
Well, that, of course, has, like everything else, good and bad points.
That sure smacks of the old boys club, which

the thing they level against the funding agencies now, I think for the institution itself, it probably is helpful to spread the blame, or as we called it back in Washington, I think it was share the responsibility, by letting somebody else in on the decision-making process so that they can't come and scalp you individually for making a bum decision.
No, I'm not
I'm particularly keen on seeing something like that.
Personally, I almost prefer to go up every two years and get judged by somebody outside the institution.
I think, as you probably figured out, or maybe you feel it yourself, that your own academic reputation frequently is a lot better outside of your institution than it is within the institution.
again, my experience, again, having been at a number of these places, is that the internal politics is dependent to such, to a large and greater extent, on non-scientific things.
You know, do you have the right car?
There's a lot of social pressure involved in this thing.
That's why I live 18 miles away from here, to keep out of it.
And that's something I learned when I went to Scripps, the first thing I
inadvertently happened to move about 10, 12 miles away from La Jolla, mainly because I couldn't afford anything closer.
And that was the luckiest thing that ever happened to me.
And ever since then, I've always done the same thing.
Again, when I was at Woods Hill, I was 13 miles from the office.
When I was in Washington, DC, I was 15 miles from the office.
And that just seems to be enough to separate your own personal social life from the place you work at.
And that's the way I prefer to fly.
But again, getting back to your question, whether it's more worthwhile having money administered locally or not, I prefer to go out outside.
I think I've gotten a better shake in what is getting on to be about 13 years since I've been in the business.
I think I get a better shake on a national level than I do internally.
Also, I think it's fairly obvious that with
funds are going to be cut, you know, for research.
I think that's a given with a combination of inflation and falling prestige of academe because of the 1960s partially.
You know, several things are involved in that, clearly.
What about the oceans?
Are they going to fall as sharply as others, or will oceanography be sort of the infield of the 70s, so to speak, with ecology and food supplies and
these sorts of cliches now becoming common.
Well, I think the ecology kick has never really done anything for us.
We've never seen anything come out of that.
I think oceanography will maintain its reasonable fair share of funding.
I don't think we're going to suffer as drastically as other
disciplines, chemistry for instance, really took it in the neck.
High energy physics, you know, probably because they were so visible.
Part of my job when I was back at the foundation was liaison for the all federally funded oceanography.
And I started accumulating statistics on who was getting what and things like this.
And I was always impressed.
I always figured a small business administration should be administering oceanography.
If you look at academic oceanography as opposed to governmental oceanography, where you can, at least I was in a position where I could get real numbers on it.
We're talking $40 million a year.
I mean, granted.
reckoning in my checking account type arithmetic, that's a lot of money, but reckoning on the federal level, it's peanuts.
That's rounding error.
I mean, sure they could wipe us out completely.
I don't think it does anything for the government to do this to us.
Again, going back to
a game we were playing at the foundation.
And we had a write-up in the budget book every year, you know, why they should be supporting science.
And again, the amount of money was so small that I thought that we ought to try to make a point that we're providing some pretty good entertainment on television.
And rather than trying to cram it into the mold of how we're going to do something wonderful for the American people to make them materially better,
you know, their standard of living or something like that.
I thought we ought to try it on the entertainment aspect.
And I got almost up to the front office with that before I got shot down.
But it really is a rather minor enterprise in the United States on the academic scene.
We happen to be, in this university, we happen to be a pretty large fraction of the grant and contract research.
In the College of Arts and Sciences,
have more bucks than all the other people in the College of Arts and Science put together.
But there's only something like 18 institutions in the United States really doing oceanography, of which maybe five or six of them are major institutions.
So again, it's kind of a small business.
I don't think we'll get much from the food aspect.
That was sort of one of the reasons I got into the business.
In the early 60s, we were going to feed the world's millions from the ocean.
And of course, the more I looked at it, the more obvious it was going to be that we weren't going to do this.
But that doesn't mean we can't use what we have more efficiently.
But the idea where we were just going to feed everybody from the ocean was really kind of silly, if you look at it.

statistics it's only something like seven percent of all the protein in the world comes from from the oceans and we'd have to get you know a hundred times as much as we're getting out or really make a much of a dent you know as far as total population is concerned a number of times i was asked to make recommendations on on this sort of thing uh
My feeling was that we'd be better off giving a guy a desalinization plant and a bag of fertilizer and a bag of seed and tell him to go out in the desert somewhere.
And as far as increasing food production goes, that was a more direct approach to the whole problem, rather than some of the things we've done in the ocean.
I think one of them, well, in the United States anyway, one of the biggest problems is food preference.
Having worked in commercial fishing
It was a part owner of a fishing boat at one time.
We used to throw away more than we'd bring home because we couldn't market it.
It wasn't worthwhile hauling it 20 miles in, put it on the dock, because it would never pay for the fuel that it took to haul it.
So we used to just throw it all back.
So maybe in some respects, you know, maybe the Russians ought to come over here
and catch the stuff, because they don't throw anything back.
They make it into fish meal or something like that.
They make a more efficient utilization of the resource that they catch, as opposed to the American fishing industry.
I'm not quite sure whether the American fishing industry would stand still for making it more efficient.
I mean, I think it's fairly clear that if we're going to get more
protein from the ocean, we're just going to have to do it more effectively and not throw the stuff back.
And when you start talking about capitalization to do this kind of thing, you don't find any large fraction of the U.S. populace with the dollars that's willing to do this.
Maybe, you know, maybe you've got to go to some sort of subsidized sort of an operation where they build factory ships and you've got to increase the size of the vessels and
American seamen don't want to go to sea for the times that it really takes to effectively fish.
They can make almost as much money pumping gas.
Why should they go to sea for 90 or 180 days at a clip?
I think, well, that gets into the whole merchant marine aspect too, but I was saying before I was down at this Polish
fisheries research vessel here in town, and these guys are away from home for 200 days a year, the scientists included.

When the ship leaves, it's got a full complement with it, and they might change the whole complement 200 days down the line or 250 days down the line, and then the guys get three months off or something like this.
But you don't find very many Americans doing that sort of a game.
I think we sort of wandered off.
No, we're still fine.
Whatever the question was.
Well, my next question, you partially answered it.
Are you very optimistic, given your line of work, about mariculture and aquaculture?
Well, the problem with aquaculture is that it's primarily a labor-intensive type of a thing.
And given the standard of living,
that we have in this country.
We have problems getting people to do that kind of work.

The reason the Japanese can do it, and I don't know how much longer they'll be able to do it, is that their standard of living is increasing rapidly and they might price themselves out of the market too.
The only thing I can see coming out of aquaculture is
luxury food items.
I don't see it coming, you know, a mainstay for protein supplements or anything like that.
But we have a number of operations in this country here that are almost breaking even, or some of them are even making money.

And there was one operation on Long Island that was making money, but that's because they were running ads in the New Yorker magazine and they were selling their clams or oysters, I forget what they were growing,
as some sort of ecologically desirable way of doing it.
So, I mean, they were selling their products to sort of an elite

group of people who were, you know, I guess they were environmentally aware or something like this, and it made them feel good to be able to eat these clams that came from this plant that was doing the right sort of thing according to their way of thinking.
But I'm sure they were paying two times as much, two to three times as much for their clams if they went down to a local fishing store or a fishing market and buy it.
I think the same is true for, well, if you look at what they're trying to produce in agriculture in the United States, it's salmon, trout, oysters, lobsters.
And if you've been to a grocery store lately, these aren't your protein backstays.
The price of them is such that you can't afford to supplement your diet.
It's not a supplement.
You have to supplement your diet with soybeans if you buy lobsters.
And I like lobsters too, but at the price lobsters are going, I'd buy some red meat.
No, I don't think aquaculture is, well, I think aquaculture is a viable business as a commercial enterprise, but I don't see it as being a tremendous boon to take protein from the marine area.
Of course, the other real problem that they run into is that they're in,
They're always in the coastal zones, which are the first ones that get the pollution impacts.
And so you have, like, Catch 23 or whatever number you want to take.
John Ryder has been growing oysters.
I can see he's grown clams, sandworms, and kelp in some sort of a system he has at Woods Hole, utilizing human sewage.
And it's a very efficient system.

system when you get to the outfall of the system you got clean water that's because everything was kept by the guys on the inside but EPA says you can't use that for human consumption so you know what you're sort of stuck you know here we've got a combination organic matter production area sewage cleanup area all at once but then what do you do with the biological material you have between the
input pipe in the outfall.
I guess you can load it on a barge and take it out to sea and dump it, but that doesn't do you much.
That seems to be one of the problems.
